DataElement.preferredName: Short Somatic Variant Unknown Significant Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A free text that describes the unknown significant of a Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) or short nucleotide insertions, deletions that originate in cells that are not destined to become gametes and are not passed on to progeny.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) or short nucleotide insertions (ins), deletions (del) or indels that originate in cells that are not destined to become gametes and are not passed on to progeny._Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused._A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) or short nucleotide insertions (ins), deletions (del) or indels that originate in cells that are not destined to become gametes and are not passed on to progeny.

Concepts.definition: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) or short nucleotide insertions (ins), deletions (del) or indels that originate in cells that are not destined to become gametes and are not passed on to progeny.

Property.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.:A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The text that provides a description of a topic.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Text; the words of something written.

ValueDomain.origin: FDA: FDA GUDID (Global Unique Device Identification Database)
